title: 111_hr4390
content: The Act titled "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" enhances program and provider protections in the Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. The Act "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" authorizes enhanced oversight periods, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations in response to significant risks of fraudulent activity in provider services under titles XVIII, XIX, or XXI. The Secretary can impose requirements on providers or suppliers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including screening, enhanced oversight periods, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations. States may also be required to implement these measures for Medicaid and CHIP. The Secretary may require States to implement screening procedures for providers and suppliers enrolling in Medicaid and CHIP programs. These procedures may include licensing board checks and screening against specified lists. Actions taken under this subsection are not subject to judicial review. The Secretary may require States to implement screening procedures for providers and suppliers enrolling in Medicaid and CHIP programs, including licensing board checks, screening against exclusion lists, background checks, site visits, and disclosure of affiliations. Providers may be subject to enhanced oversight for a period of 30 to 365 days with required or unannounced site visits. The Secretary may require enhanced oversight for providers and suppliers enrolling in Medicaid and CHIP programs, including site visits, inspections, prepayment review, and claims review. The oversight period can be extended beyond 365 days if deemed necessary. Enhanced oversight for claims of durable medical equipment suppliers may be implemented if there is a significant risk of fraudulent activity. The Secretary may withhold payment for durable medical equipment supplied by a provider identified for enhanced oversight under Medicaid and CHIP programs. Additionally, a program will be established for periodic review of physician authorizations in cases of excessive prescribing or authorization of items or services. The Secretary may withhold payment for durable medical equipment supplied by a provider identified for enhanced oversight under Medicaid and CHIP programs. A program will be established for periodic review of physician authorizations in cases of excessive prescribing or authorization of items or services. Physicians or health care professionals will receive a quarterly list of claims based on their prescriptions or authorizations, and if they do not validate the legitimacy within 90 days, claims related to those items or services will be affected. The Secretary may impose a moratorium on enrollment of providers and suppliers in cases of serious ongoing fraud within Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs to prevent adverse impacts. The Secretary may impose a moratorium on provider enrollment to prevent fraud, ensuring access to care. States can conduct additional provider oversight. A probationary period for new providers is established for heightened review. The Secretary may conduct reviews of claims to determine provider legitimacy, validate physician prescriptions, and suspend or terminate providers with notice if a significant number of claims are deemed illegitimate. The Secretary may suspend or terminate a provider or supplier's participation with notice. Failure to cooperate in validating prescriptions may result in a civil monetary penalty of up to $10,000. Civil money penalties will be imposed in accordance with section 1128A. The text discusses revisions to Prompt Pay Provisions in the Social Security Act, specifically addressing claims of providers or suppliers suspected of fraudulent activities. The amendments aim to enhance oversight and prevent fraudulent claim submissions. The Medicaid section of the Social Security Act is amended to enforce determinations made by the Secretary regarding fraudulent activity. The State will enforce determinations made by the Secretary regarding fraudulent activity in provider categories under the Medicaid and CHIP programs. The State will enforce determinations made by the Secretary regarding fraudulent activity in provider categories under the Medicaid and CHIP programs through specified procedures. Medicare providers and suppliers must comply with program integrity requirements outlined in section 1128G. In implementing program integrity requirements for Medicare providers and suppliers, the Secretary of Health and Human Services must consult with the Inspector General to identify areas at risk of fraudulent activity. Additional funding is authorized for this purpose. The text discusses additional funding authorized for program integrity requirements to prevent fraud and abuse in Medicare, Medicaid, and the State children's health insurance program. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the enactment of the Act, with expedited implementation for providers and suppliers approved for participation six months after the enactment date. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will implement regulations within 6 months of the Act's enactment to ensure program integrity and prevent fraud in Medicare, Medicaid, and the State children's health insurance program. The regulations will be effective immediately on an interim basis, with a period for public comments before any revisions can be made.
